9F0163110B2841D182F490F4A5EB6B07.description: Give examples of inventions and technologies created in Canada. Examples: kayaks, snowmobiles, Canadarm, insulin, canola.

F1A51BB7E400465CA07290AFF5EF8454.description: Give examples of ways in which industry and technology have changed life in Canada since 1945. Examples: urbanization, transportation, communication, education.

2834ACFDDFA14ADA9A568A86E2B5E3A2.description: Give examples of the impact of technological development on life in Canada from 1914 to 1945. Examples: electricity, telecommunication, transportation, medicine, industrialization.

CBBE195916964CC69504CB9B2A6674C4.description: Relate stories of the Depression and describe its impact on Canada. Examples: changes in agricultural practices, development of the social safety net, new political parties.

2A96A512753F443391A2F145AB9D7318.description:
Explain the importance of agriculture in the
development of Canada from 1867 to 1914.

479038FC3D1B4A05A272C8CF3D05B9F3.description: Identify factors that contribute to inequities in Canada and propose solutions. Examples: poverty, racism, sexism.

7037A9B339E94D50B575BBF42D8EC303.description: Identify and describe the main responsibilities of elected representatives of their Aboriginal community.

617A240361D04208A28CB7CD077B9A86.description: Identify elected or appointed municipal, provincial, and federal government representatives and describe their main responsibilities. Include: Governor General, Manitoba Lieutenant-Governor.

287305B996204461A3AFD9DDA11DC366.description: Identify the main responsibilities of municipal, provincial, First Nations, and federal governments in Canada.

0AC16C8D3A6D4D35AB749A088FBC3117.description: Describe characteristics of the electoral processes in Canada.

509C5E34206046E6A50D09F7FE64DB25.description: Define the term political party and identify political parties and their leaders in Canada.

413A828E4C0D46D6917BC16DCC522F25.description: Describe the main features of the Canadian government. Include: parliamentary system, federal democracy.

D2A52F7A1C214320B0E0E1E27B36749C.description: Identify First Nations, Inuit, and Métis perspectives regarding self-determination. Examples: resource use, land claims, treaties, government.

1E588BCD40824D71A4C45E6C08DC07D9.description:
Describe the struggle for and identify
individuals involved in women’s suffrage in
Manitoba and Canada.
Include: Famous Five (Emily Murphy,
Henrietta Muir Edwards, Louise McKinney,
Nellie McClung, and Irene Parlby).

6D8AC929CEE5444F93E601A3D94A0AA3.description: Give examples of Canada’s connections to other regions of the world. Examples: environmental, social, political, economic.

31568FB3396B44A79E9A99BCAAA4AD25.description: Give examples of Canada’s participation in the United Nations and other international organizations. Examples: the Commonwealth, La Francophonie, Organization of American States.

27F4BAC8F31A4E2882DB41E220811DB0.description: Give examples of global events and forces that have affected Canadians from 1945 to the present. Examples: international cooperation, relief efforts, disease, environmental changes, famine, refugee movement.

DAE733B7FE1641319AD5D76DBE2EB1F6.description: Give examples of Canada’s involvement in world conflicts since 1945. Examples: Korean War, Cold War, Gulf War, Bosnia, Afghanistan, international peacekeeping.

E42DABA1B0ED482AA686289EB37894E6.description: Describe Canada’s involvement in the Second World War and identify its impact on Canadian individuals and communities. Include: internment of ethnocultural groups; the Holocaust.

586BE73A9BFB404BA4E42EA962C02780.description: Identify major causes and events of the Second World War.

034657815315483580DDBF4FE18ED359.description: Describe Canada’s involvement in the First World War and identify its impact on Canadian individuals and communities. Include: internment of ethnocultural groups.

FE08A43E256444708CFAAD367284985C.description:
Identify major causes and events of the First
World War.

3C578430AD70485D9CF67B79E69AF9F4.description: Identify the prime ministers of Canada from 1945 to the present and give examples of their achievements.

76B790ED111445DF9B7CAA71B0361C8A.description: Describe changing roles for women in Canada from 1914 to 1945.

A627CFC1083749FFBEDBF9CFA8421A4E.description: Identify the prime ministers of Canada from 1914 to 1945 and give examples of their achievements.

95611CDEB2744909B5BCB67C74B848B5.description: Describe the causes, main events, and results of the 1919 Winnipeg General Strike.

1C4CF9D2CA5B4ABCA8B4488F7C14284B.description: Identify the prime ministers of Canada from 1867 to 1914 and give examples of their achievements.

118847E3D3194F978E8E5D0551A6827A.description: Identify factors leading to the entry into Confederation of Manitoba, Northwest Territories, British Columbia, Prince Edward Island, Yukon, Saskatchewan, Alberta, Newfoundland and Labrador, and Nunavut, and specify the year of entry.

D19922C04DDE4BFDA364E688B1CA95DD.description: Identify contributions of Aboriginal leaders from 1867 to 1914. Examples: Gabriel Dumont, Mistahimaskwa (Big Bear), Pitikwahanapiwiyin (Poundmaker), Isapomuxika (Crowfoot).

3872E44683C747F58E64C11104E70101.description: Identify events and issues related to the construction of the Canadian Pacific Railway. Examples: workers and working conditions, Chinese labourers, construction difficulties, mapping Canada.

A67A35BD7CDC4CA984BB313FB2767153.description: Relate stories about the gold rushes and describe the impact of the gold rushes on individuals and communities. Examples: Fraser River, Cariboo, Klondike.

97D00F6E07FD4F8B9E2C1C4CFFD98F0C.description: Describe the role of the North West Mounted Police.

D9406C2DDE174150AA53698F3FE31E95.description: Identify causes, events, individuals, and consequences of the 1885 Resistance.

901F8037ECF94724BBFA56341A64D08A.description: Identify the roles of Father Noël-Joseph Ritchot and Archbishop Alexandre-Antonin Taché in Manitoba's entry into Confederation.

A6EDD6C15AD14185B59178D1DC3FCDB0.description:
Identify individuals and events connected
with Manitoba’s entry into Confederation.
Include: Louis Riel, Red River Resistance,
Métis Bill of Rights, provisional government.

6E67601757E247BAB9E28AAB7D9362B7.description: Describe the influence of the land on their First Nation, Inuit, or Métis identity. Examples: values, beliefs, traditions, customs, art, clothing.

7ED0EAAE602F42E49BC04750818AAA65.description: Describe the influence of the natural environment on life in Canada.

3B8E199CCDE4437ABE1B69BC03E76BD8.description: Locate on a map of Canada the provinces, territories, and capital cities.

32261B778897461B84F0B6C786B1F030.description: Give examples of the influence of the natural environment on daily life for various groups during the Depression.

549EEC42C0AF448F8B08748542DF2D87.description: Locate on a map the major settlements of Rupert’s Land and the original provinces of Canada in 1867.

78CA5FB963A34DE6A7FE031DD79A0922.description:
Locate on a map of Canada the major
landforms and bodies of water.

07436D7263F44FD395059093D8F6307D.description: Identify various individuals from Canada’s past and present, and describe their achievements.

9CB40C350E0E4CA8AFC516661C9266AF.description: Describe the role of francophone organizations and identify ways in which they promote francophone rights. Examples: Société franco-manitobaine, Pluri-Elles.

73000EAE2F444BC0BA9A13407D7B38B8.description: Identify the roles of Aboriginal organizations and give examples of ways in which they promote Aboriginal rights. Examples: Assembly of Manitoba Chiefs, Manitoba Métis Federation, Assembly of First Nations, Métis National Council.

E99B0406424A43EDACCA5E3142974217.description: Identify various groups and organizations that may contribute to personal identity.

A5978EF6865B4AA39CF985E2BC6797AC.description: Give examples from the arts and media that are expressions of Canadian culture and/or identity.

90D767A69CD94092A137649E6658986D.description: Give examples of ways in which the government helps protect Canadian identity. Examples: Canadian content rules in the media; support for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and the arts.

7359986009F348058B1C3ED105E057AD.description: Describe characteristics that define Canada as a country. Examples: multicultural, bilingual, northern.

9E5F061CB5FE4823B8E26780DF598EB1.description: Describe the influence of their social, cultural, and linguistic choices on their francophone identities.

FB1DEB8778954AF99DF1A913F75E9646.description: Describe factors that shape personal and national identities and explain how they may coexist. Examples: social, cultural, linguistic.

1D4A3C5565114943AD42CB6814895669.description: Identify events surrounding the creation of the Division scolaire franco-manitobaine (DSFM). Examples: Manitoba Schools Question, Bill 113, Article 23 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the Mahé Ruling, the Manitoba Referral.

7EF2B76CD02742BAB4C12BBCC24B9D5E.description: Give examples of changes to francophone populations in Canada since Confederation. Examples: characteristics, distribution.

20AABF3551AD4DD881230629014C84B4.description: Identify changes and developments regarding Aboriginal rights in Canada from 1867 to the present. Examples: suffrage, changes to Status and entitlement, self-governance, land claims, new treaties...

1D7A7E3A608B4264BBD5A183AC2357E3.description: Describe the impact of the Affaire Forest on the linguistic rights of Franco-manitobains.

D9A0D2956C5445E99793709B1FA47DC1.description: Identify historical reasons for bilingual and multicultural policies in Canada.

FEA197B53D2F4861865E208110D888A3.description: Identify contributions of First Nations, Inuit, and Métis peoples to Canada’s war efforts.

EB0D330D44AF4CBA89822528F0E8E02E.description: Describe daily life on a prairie homestead between 1890 and 1914. Examples: survey system, role of women, challenges facing early settlers, education.

CB6A7224D4F44DD989FD95C9B80156B1.description: Describe various challenges faced by new immigrants to Canada. Examples: language, climate and environment, differing laws and customs, discrimination, physical and cultural isolation.

9F070D9568E042EB9CB6ED43F80B1FEC.description: Describe ways in which immigration was encouraged by and important to the Canadian government from 1867 to 1914.

5EA7F700511D4FD8987E56062CD6EEDA.description: Identify various groups that immigrated to Canada in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and give reasons for their emigration. Examples: African-Americans, Asians, British, Central and Eastern Europeans, Icelanders.

02C43B3E7B554F6BA8B67A7FC9743BFD.description:
Give reasons for the establishment of treaties and
reserves and describe their impact on individuals,
families, and communities.
Examples: indigenous rights, no right to vote, permission
needed to leave a reserve.

B6D46A0B38BF43EC81495DC7826CE3E8.description: Identify current issues related to citizenship in Canada.

206C2AAF44E24B80BCD1BF00B690F16A.description: Identify rights and freedoms described in the 1982 Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and explain why they are important.

5CE4E348479F4184AF5177236869985F.description: Identify the ideals of democracy and describe the influence of democracy on quality of life for Canadians.

5EB886C043A0462296A9566999B4B3F7.description: Recognize Remembrance Day as a commemoration of Canadian participation in world conflicts.

C642FCCCA585459D918A62C8D151DDDC.description: Compare responsibilities and rights of citizens of Canada at the time of Confederation to those of today. Include: Aboriginal peoples, francophones, women.

099136512B5649A3BC8069DD262827F8.description:
Explain the significance of the British North
America Act.
Examples: federal system of government,
constitutional monarchy, British-style
parliament.

025496C20EEB418FB3EB0124F7DEC689.description: Elicit and clarify questions and ideas in discussions. S-405 Articulate their beliefs and perspectives on issues

DEA0083263DD4E968504D3F470E2CF2B.description: Present information and ideas orally, visually, concretely, or electronically.

0256A2AA89A34F749C4E66CBDFB94EF9.description: Persuasively express differing viewpoints regarding an issue.

71191B1718F54020AD2AED8D81C8EEFE.description: Use language that is respectful of human diversity.

0D32E038ABC14150BD5425C704ED8032.description:
Listen to others to understand their
perspectives.

CDF2A68BFF6A4D2E84E28B7C83832D17.description: Recognize that interpretations of history are subject to change as new information is uncovered or acknowledged.

AE622B4952F74292898CACAF995BC579.description: Interpret information and ideas in a variety of media. Examples: art, music, historical fiction, drama, primary sources.

3049F57E3C0640E490172B2E79921709.description: Compare diverse perspectives in a variety of information sources.

35B44F4663974116BDA5D06400B14CA3.description: Compare differing accounts of historical events.

A9892C3F2E924CF5949DF46AA1D34FF2.description: Assess the validity of information sources. Examples: purpose, context, authenticity, origin, objectivity, evidence, reliability...

F9715DD2EEDD4B4AAB8B5EEA04018F4C.description: Observe and analyze material and visual evidence for research. Examples: artifacts, photographs, works of art.

176CCA7A34734AD18F41CD2BAF624A0B.description: Distinguish fact from opinion and interpretation.

6B8384C7351F4D52AD63BED197CED2D3.description: Evaluate personal assumptions based on new information and ideas.

9F22B5C0A5994BCB9AEF03BCFF3BEDB0.description: Draw conclusions based on research and evidence.

8F2F96C54E38413DB74B320A799A0E66.description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of solutions to a problem.

F61E6FDF754647FB845D2999755FA73C.description:
Plan topics, goals, and methods for historical
inquiry and research.

9CE633C93F6F4E10805E049FC41A0CED.description: Orient themselves by observing the landscape, using traditional knowledge, or using a compass or other tools and technologies

D844B208B67E489A9963473DF7F26B1C.description: Use traditional knowledge to read the land.

3CCB18DE42A844C59077700820594F00.description: Use latitude and longitude to locate and describe places on maps and globes.

E691990EFD22482AADF5227ED88DD30B.description: Select and interpret various types of maps for specific purposes.

63724B5017C84D86BD6C9A2849E60005.description: Construct maps that include a title, legend, compass rose, scale, and latitude and longitude.

45CA30519B4D40D7A20F5544E889B5A6.description: Create timelines and other visual organizers to sequence and represent historical figures, relationships, or chronological events.

F85E81CF9DEB4129A8B9CE8B48C7FB2F.description: Select and use appropriate tools and technologies to accomplish tasks.

FD326970F42E4654B24B9A82248B4DE1.description: Distinguish between primary and secondary information sources for research.

CEFDB45F35BC49ADB655710BA5845841.description: Organize and record information in a variety of formats and reference sources appropriately. Examples: maps, charts, outlines, concept maps.

B2E11E0948D04BA7B45CDEA95E5A91BE.description:
Select information from oral, visual, material,
print, or electronic sources.
Examples: maps, atlases, art, songs, artifacts,
narratives, legends, biographies, historical
fiction.

E506C2DFF741465DB2F7BF81D2AEFC86.description: Treat places and objects of historical significance with respect. Examples: burial grounds, memorials, artifacts.

E96A486592CB406EBDED0D9EFBA0ABB6.description: Recognize bias and discrimination and propose solutions.

6EEFF85C935C43149477B1B596E044D3.description: Negotiate constructively with others to build consensus and solve problems.

EE9354219F184C1C9D087C448C475053.description: Make decisions that reflect care, concern, and responsibility for the environment.

D858C89452E040399482B59204D11113.description: Make decisions that reflect fairness and equality in their interactions with others.

E980D2FA55E74C87929D188B22716DD8.description: Use a variety of strategies to resolve conflicts peacefully and fairly. Examples: clarification, negotiation, compromise.

2DDA06E0F5B843D5905FC035F1134D44.description:
Collaborate with others to establish and carry
out group goals and responsibilities.
